GENERAL.A substantial increase in unemployment is again reported. This is due, almost entirely, to the shortage of fuel supplies consequent upon the coal dispute. Unemployment is likely to increase rapidly within the next week or two unless a settlement is reached. Fresh discharges have taken place from ironworks in the North of England and Scotland, and engineering firms are finding increased difficulty in carrying on their work. The shortage of coal has also resulted in the closing down of a large number of brickworks, while unemployment has increased considerably among pottery and glass workers. The shipyards are not materially affected by the coal shortage, but they have very little work in hand. The position in the textile trades remains unchanged, but a number of firms in the hosiery trade have been compelled to make further restrictions in their working hours. Although increasing orders are being received in the cotton trade the shortage of fuel prevents any considerable expansion of business. There is still some improvement in the boot trade at Northampton.II. (The additional labour still required was 9,690 skilled men and 484 unskilled.)Total labour employed on above schemes = 218,497.As reports for the week ended the 29th April have been received from only 345 Local Authorities out of 399 who were asked to furnish information, it is probable that the Relief Schemes which have been inaugurated by the Government and Local Authorities are finding employment for a number of men in excess of the figures given.III. 50,000 EX-SERVICE MEN TO BE TRAINED IN THE BUILDINGINDUSTRY.The Employers' Associations are taking steps to set up throughout the country the District Committees which are to he established to select applicants and allocate them to the trades in which they can be trained most suitably. The number of applications received to date totals 11,557. In the London and South-Eastern Division 5,589 men have applied, and the following are figures for other divisions: South Midlands and Eastern Counties, 743; South-Western Counties, 808; West Midlands, 907; Yorkshire and East Midlands, 1,082; North-Western Counties, 1,487; Northern Division, 236; Scotland, 596; Wales, 109.
